newsitem.title: JAPAN: Dlr steady after tight range trade in late Tokyo.
newsitem.headline: Dlr steady after tight range trade in late Tokyo.

text.p: The dollar moved steadily against the yen after trading in a range around 126.80-127.00 yen by late Tokyo on Wednesday. It was sandwiched between bids from Japanese operators and option-linked sales, dealers said.
Trading energy ebbed in the afternoon amid an absence of decisive factors. Action mostly focused on option-related trade, they said.
The dollar failed to clearly break through 127 yen as option-linked sales, mostly by interbank dealers, to avoid hitting knock-out options points near 127.30 yen limited its advance, dealers said.
But they said buy-back interest from those dealers also kept the greenback solid on the downside.

Other factors to cap the dollar's advance were rises in the yield of the key 182nd 10-year Japanese government bond and in Tokyo stocks, dealers said. "We are closely watching a rise in Japanese long-term interest rates," a dealer said. The 182nd JGB yield was 2.350 percent at 0640 GMT against Monday's 2.295.
Tokyo stocks surged upwards, with a rally mostly inspired by a surge on Wall Street on Tuesday. The Nikkei average of 225 leading shares ended up 480.75 points at 19,151.12.

In the morning, the greenback was well-bid versus the yen despite falls against the mark overnight in reaction to weaker-than-expected U.S. economic data, which dulled expectations of a near-term rise in U.S. interest rates.

Dealers said trust banks were actively buying dollars, probably on behalf of investment trust firms and pension funds. Mark buying for yen in cross-trade in late morning also supported the greenback versus the yen, they said.

The mark rose as high as around 73.79 yen in late morning trade after stop-loss mark buying was set off near 73.60-65 yen. This dragged the dollar down against the mark briefly, while pushing up the dollar against the yen, dealers said.
The mark stood around 73.57/60 yen at 0704 GMT, compared with 73.55 yen in early Tokyo trading.

Lingering worries about possible dollar-selling intervention if the dollar manages to advance above 127 yen continued to weigh on the dollar against the yen. But a city bank dealer said: "While we are concerned about it, it's unlikely that intervention will take place."

One bank dealer said comments by former MOF official Toyoo Gyohten that the yen had fallen too far blocked the dollar's rise in the morning. "The current level of the Japanese yen is excessively weak," Gyohten said in Washington.

U.S. Treasury Secretary Robert Rubin repeated his mantra that a strong dollar is in U.S. interests but said he shared Japanese concerns on a weak yen. But the impact from these comments was limited. Singapore dealers said the dollar looked well-bid on the downside and was unlikely to fall below 1.7150 marks and 126.50 yen. -- Singapore newsroom +65-8703080, Tokyo Treasury Desk +81-3-3432-8584
